elements.content: Two novel three-dimensional frameworks Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy)·0.5H2CDC·1.25H2O (1) and Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe) (2) (CDC = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate; 4,4‘-Bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine; 4,4‘-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) have been synthesized and structurally rationalized to have doubly interpenetrating elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) nets based on a binuclear paddle-wheel motif and its enlarged dimer, respectively. Framework 1 shows one-dimensional pores filled with trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids, while framework 2 is a condensed structure because of the enlarged building block.
elements.clean_text: Two novel three-dimensional frameworks Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy)⋅0.5H2CDC⋅1.25H2O (1) and Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe) (2) (CDC = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate; 4,4‘-Bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine; 4,4‘-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) have been synthesized and structurally rationalized to have doubly interpenetrating elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) nets based on a binuclear paddle-wheel motif and its enlarged dimer, respectively. Framework 1 shows one-dimensional pores filled with trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids, while framework 2 is a condensed structure because of the enlarged building block.

elements.content: Two novel doubly interpenetrating elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) nets based on a binuclear paddle-wheel motif and its enlarged dimer, respectively, have been synthesized and structurally rationalized.
elements.clean_text: Two novel doubly interpenetrating elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) nets based on a binuclear paddle-wheel motif and its enlarged dimer, respectively, have been synthesized and structurally rationalized.

elements.content: There has been extensive interest in metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), not only for their potential applications in gas storage, separation, magnetism, nonlinear optics, luminescence, and catalysis but also for their rational design principles to construct intriguing architectures and topologies. By incorporation of paddle-wheel M2(COO)4(H2O)2 (M2+ = Cu2+ and Zn2+) building blocks with a variety of organic linkers, a series of highly porous and stable MOFs with predictable structures, and tunable pore sizes and functionalities, have been realized (Scheme , Approach I). Recently, Kim, Hupp, and ourselves have started another strategy to construct pillared paddle-wheel frameworks for their functional properties by making use of dicarboxylic acids and bridging bidentate organic linkers (Scheme , Approach II). The pores of such synthesized MOFs can be systematically tuned by judicious choices of the dicarboxylic acids and bridging linkers, and by framework interpenetration. Our recently reported microporous MOF Zn2(BDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy), exhibiting one-dimensional (1D) pores of about 4.0 × 4.0 Å to discriminate linear and branched alkanes, has been successfully applied to the gas chromatographic separation of alkanes. In our endeavor to assemble trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids with paddle-wheel copper motifs into its MOFs, we found a novel secondary building block composed of two paddle-wheel copper motifs (copper paddle-wheel dimers) to construct the α-Po net (Scheme , Approach III). Herein we report the syntheses and crystal structures of Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy)·0.5H2CDC·1.25H2O (1) and Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe) (2) (CDC = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate; 4,4‘-Bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine; 4,4‘-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene)) in which paddle-wheel copper building blocks and their dimers have been assembled into their doubly interpenetrated α-Po nets, respectively.
elements.clean_text: There has been extensive interest in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), not only for their potential applications in gas storage, separation, magnetism, nonlinear optics, luminescence, and catalysis but also for their rational design principles to construct intriguing architectures and topologies. By incorporation of paddle-wheel M2(COO)4(H2O)2 (M2+ = Cu2+ and Zn2+) building blocks with a variety of organic linkers, a series of highly porous and stable MOFs with predictable structures, and tunable pore sizes and functionalities, have been realized (Scheme , Approach I). Recently, Kim, Hupp, and ourselves have started another strategy to construct pillared paddle-wheel frameworks for their functional properties by making use of dicarboxylic acids and bridging bidentate organic linkers (Scheme , Approach II). The pores of such synthesized MOFs can be systematically tuned by judicious choices of the dicarboxylic acids and bridging linkers, and by framework interpenetration. Our recently reported microporous MOF Zn2(BDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy), exhibiting one-dimensional (1D) pores of about 4.0 × 4.0 Å to discriminate linear and branched alkanes, has been successfully applied to the gas chromatographic separation of alkanes. In our endeavor to assemble trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids with paddle-wheel copper motifs into its MOFs, we found a novel secondary building block composed of two paddle-wheel copper motifs (copper paddle-wheel dimers) to construct the α-Po net (Scheme , Approach III). Herein we report the syntheses and crystal structures of Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy)⋅0.5H2CDC⋅1.25H2O (1) and Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe) (2) (CDC = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate; 4,4‘-Bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine; 4,4‘-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene)) in which paddle-wheel copper building blocks and their dimers have been assembled into their doubly interpenetrated α-Po nets, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized by the reaction of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.0613 g, 0.264 mmol), H2CDC (0.0689 g, 0.400 mmol), and 4,4‘-Bipy (0.0206 g, 0.132 mmol) in H2O (15 mL) at 80 °C for 72 h as very small blue, blade-shaped crystals, the largest being slightly less than 0.1 mm in the longest dimension. The formula of the compound was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the phase purity of the bulk material was independently confirmed by elemental microanalysis, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). As expected, the framework of 1 contains paddle-wheel binuclear Cu2 units (Figure a), which are bridged by CDC dianions to form a distorted two-dimensional (2D) square grid {Cu2(CDC)2}. These 2D square grids are further pillared by 4,4‘-bipyridine, occupying the axial sites of the Cu2 paddle wheels, to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure. The topology of 1 can be best described as an elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) net (Figure b). The overall structure of 1 is a pair of identical α-Po nets of Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy), which are mutually interpenetrated with each other to form a doubly interpenetrating 3D framework. The pores of 1 along the 2D square grid {Cu2(CDC)2} are fully filled with 4,4‘-bipyridine molecules from another α-Po net (Figure c), while the pores viewed along the rectangular grid {Cu2(CDC)(4,4‘-Bipy)} are significantly reduced by double interpenetration of the 3D frameworks. Overall, there exists a 1D channel along the rectangular diagonal of the paddle-wheel clusters which are filled with free trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was synthesized by the reaction of Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (0.0613 g, 0.264 mmol), H2CDC (0.0689 g, 0.400 mmol), and 4,4‘-Bipy (0.0206 g, 0.132 mmol) in H2O (15 mL) at 80 °C for 72 h as very small blue, blade-shaped crystals, the largest being slightly less than 0.1 mm in the longest dimension. The formula of the compound was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the phase purity of the bulk material was independently confirmed by elemental microanalysis, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). As expected, the framework of 1 contains paddle-wheel binuclear Cu2 units (Figure a), which are bridged by CDC dianions to form a distorted two-dimensional (2D) square grid {Cu2(CDC)2}. These 2D square grids are further pillared by 4,4‘-bipyridine, occupying the axial sites of the Cu2 paddle wheels, to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure. The topology of 1 can be best described as an elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) net (Figure b). The overall structure of 1 is a pair of identical α-Po nets of Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy), which are mutually interpenetrated with each other to form a doubly interpenetrating 3D framework. The pores of 1 along the 2D square grid {Cu2(CDC)2} are fully filled with 4,4‘-bipyridine molecules from another α-Po net (Figure c), while the pores viewed along the rectangular grid {Cu2(CDC)(4,4‘-Bipy)} are significantly reduced by double interpenetration of the 3D frameworks. Overall, there exists a 1D channel along the rectangular diagonal of the paddle-wheel clusters which are filled with free trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids (Figure d).

Selected Bond Distances (Å) and Angles (deg) for Compounds1 and 2

Cu2(C8H10O4)2(C10H8N2)·0.5(C8H12O4)·1.25(H2O) (1) a Cu1−O3 1.967 (5) O1−Cu1−O5ii 167.7 (2) Cu1−O7i 1.972 (5) O3−Cu1−N2iii 96.2 (2) Cu1−O1 1.986 (6) O7i−Cu1−N2iii 94.3 (2) Cu1−O5ii 1.996 (6) O1−Cu1−N2iii 96.8 (2) Cu1−N2iii 2.156 (6) O5ii−Cu1−N2iii 95.5 (2) Cu1−Cu2 2.6169 (14) O2−Cu2−O6ii 169.0 (2) Cu2−O2 1.957 (6) O2−Cu2−O8i 89.7 (2) Cu2−O6ii 1.972 (6) O6ii−Cu2−O8i 87.9 (2) Cu2−O8i 1.984 (5) O2−Cu2−O4 90.0 (2) Cu2−O4 1.986 (5) O6ii−Cu2−O4 89.9 (2) Cu2−N1 2.146 (6) O8i−Cu2−O4 167.3 (2) O3−Cu1−O7i 169.5 (2) O2−Cu2−N1 93.8 (2) O3−Cu1−O1 89.4 (3) O6ii−Cu2−N1 97.1 (2) O7i−Cu1−O1 90.7 (3) O8i−Cu2−N1 98.2 (2) O3−Cu1−O5ii 89.8 (3) O4−Cu2−N1 94.5 (2) O7i−Cu1−O5ii 87.8 (3) Cu4(C8H10O4)4(C12H10N2) (2) b Cu1−O3 1.951 (4) O7−Cu1−O5 164.52 (18) Cu1−O1 1.970 (4) O3−Cu1−N1 95.8 (2) Cu1−O7 1.982 (4) O1−Cu1−N1 94.63 (19) Cu1−O5 1.988 (4) O7−Cu1−N1 104.11 (19) Cu1−N1 2.148 (5) O5−Cu1−N1 91.3 (2) Cu1−Cu2 2.6140 (18) O6−Cu2−O4 90.63 (18) Cu2−O6 1.952 (4) O6−Cu2−O2 88.46 (18) Cu2−O4 1.957 (4) O4−Cu2−O2 168.47 (19) Cu2−O2 1.958 (4) O6−Cu2−O8 173.93 (18) Cu2−O8 1.991 (4) O4−Cu2−O8 89.22 (18) Cu2−O8i 2.227 (4) O2−Cu2−O8 90.48 (18) O3−Cu1−O1 169.58 (18) O6−Cu2−O8i 107.03 (17) O3−Cu1−O7 87.57 (19) O4−Cu2−O8i 96.12 (18) O1−Cu1−O7 90.76 (19) O2−Cu2−O8i 95.14 (17) O3−Cu1−O5 89.98 (19) O8−Cu2−O8i 79.02 (19) O1−Cu1−O5 88.89 (19)

a  Symmetry codes:  (i) x − 1, y, z; (ii) x, y − 1, z; (iii) x, y, 1 + z. b  Symmetry codes:  (i) 1 − x, 1 − y, 2 − z.

Compound 2 was similarly synthesized by the reaction of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.0563 g, 0.242 mmol), H2CDC (0.063 g, 0.366 mmol), and 4,4‘-Bpe (0.0221 g, 0.121 mmol) in H2O (15 mL) at 80 °C for 72 h as small blue-green block-shaped crystals around 0.1 mm in maximum dimension. The formula of the compound was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the phase purity of the bulk material was independently confirmed by elemental microanalysis, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). We expected that the longer pillar linker 4,4‘-Bpe will lead to another α-Po net with larger pores or high interpenetration. To our surprise, the structure of 2 reveals that the framework is composed of a novel centrosymmetric tetranuclear Cu4(CDC)4 building block (Figure a). This new type of tetranuclear building block can be viewed as the enlarged binuclear paddle-wheel motif by bridging one of the two copper ions with a carboxylate oxygen atom from another paddle-wheel cluster in the axial position, i.e., paddle-wheel dimer. The bond distances and angles in the Cu4(CDC)4 paddle-wheel dimer of 2 are comparable to those in the Cu2(CDC)2 paddle-wheel monomer of 1, as shown Table . Such a paddle-wheel dimer motif has been reported in some Rh(II)-carboxylate compounds and is part of the infinite chain in some anhydrous Cu(II)-carboxylates. These enlarged dimers are bridged by CDC dianions to form a distorted 2D square grid {Cu4(CDC)4}, which are further pillared by 4,4‘-Bpe to construct a 3D structure (Figure b). The paddle-wheel dimer can be also topologically viewed as an octahedral node, and the topology of 2 can be best described as an elongated primitive cubic (α-Po) net. Simplifying the node as an Po atom in the center of Cu4(CDC)4 cluster, the overall structure of 2 is a pair of identical α-Po nets of Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe), which are mutually interpenetrated with each other to form a doubly interpenetrating 3D framework (Figure c). Here the significantly larger paddle-wheel dimer building block leads to the formation of a condensed structure of 2 (Figure d), although the pillar linker trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene in 2 is longer than 4,4‘-bipyridine in 1.

To our surprise, the structure of 2 reveals that the framework is composed of a novel centrosymmetric tetranuclear Cu4(CDC)4 building block (Figure a). elements.content: Structure of1 showing (a) the coordination geometry of the paddle-wheel Cu2(CDC)2(4,4‘-Bipy) unit, (b) its α-Po net viewed along the b-axis (hydrogen atoms are omitted for the clarity; Cu green; N blue; O red; C gray); (c) space-filling representation of the side view of the doubly interpenetrating frameworks indicating the pores along the 2D square grid {Cu2(CDC)2} (purple) are fully filled with 4,4‘-bipyridine molecules from another α-Po net (green), while (d) the pores viewed along the rectangular grid {Cu2(CDC)(4,4‘-Bipy)} are significantly reduced by the framework interpenetration and filled with free trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids (O, C, and H are shown in red, gray, and white, respectively, for free trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acids).

elements.content: Structure of2 showing (a) the coordination geometry of the paddle-wheel dimer Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe) unit; (b) its α-Po net viewed along the a-axis (hydrogen atoms are omitted for the clarity; Cu green; N blue; O red; C gray); (c) schematic illustration of the doubly interpenetrating frameworks in purple and green (center of the paddle-wheel dimer as the Po node); and (d) its corresponding space-filling representation indicating the formation of a condensed structure.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure of2 showing (a) the coordination geometry of the paddle-wheel dimer Cu4(CDC)4(4,4‘-Bpe) unit; (b) its α-Po net viewed along the a-axis (hydrogen atoms are omitted for the clarity; Cu green; N blue; O red; C gray); (c) schematic illustration of the doubly interpenetrating frameworks in purple and green (center of the paddle-wheel dimer as the Po node); and (d) its corresponding space-filling representation indicating the formation of a condensed structure.

elements.content: The reason for the in situ formation of the paddle-wheel dimer in 2 instead of simple paddle-wheel motif in 1 is still not clear, as both reactions were carried out under the same conditions. It has been known that limiting the availability of exogenous ligands at slightly higher temperature favors the formation of a paddle-wheel dimer, and the activation energy from a binuclear paddle-wheel to its tetranuclear paddle-wheel dimer is comparatively small in the formation of anhydrous copper carboxylates from their hydrate precursors. We speculate that the tendency to form a condensed framework of the solid to maximize the van der Waals interactions between the interpenetrated frameworks is the driving force for such a building block formation. By judicious choices of the dicarboxylic acids and bridging linkers, we should be able to incorporate this type of new building block into MOFs with novel porosity and magnetic properties, which we are currently pursuing.
elements.clean_text: The reason for the in situ formation of the paddle-wheel dimer in 2 instead of simple paddle-wheel motif in 1 is still not clear, as both reactions were carried out under the same conditions. We speculate that the tendency to form a condensed framework of the solid to maximize the van der Waals interactions between the interpenetrated frameworks is the driving force for such a building block formation. By judicious choices of the dicarboxylic acids and bridging linkers, we should be able to incorporate this type of new building block into MOFs with novel porosity and magnetic properties, which we are currently pursuing.

elements.content: X-ray data in CIF format; powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of as-synthesized compounds 1 and 2 and simulated patterns from the X-ray single crystal structures of 1 and 2; TGA plots of 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
α-Po Nets of Copper(II)-trans-1,4-Cyclohexanedicarboxylate Frameworks Based
on a Paddle-Wheel Building Block and Its Enlarged Dimer
